title: Éamonn Ó Catháin
text:
Éamonn Ó Catháin is an Irish <a href="chef">chef</a>, <a href="author">author</a> and <a href="journalist">journalist</a> and <a href="News%20presenter">broadcaster</a>.
Career.
Ó Catháin was born in <a href="Belfast">Belfast</a>, <a href="Northern%20Ireland">Northern Ireland</a> but moved to <a href="Wales">Wales</a> at age 18, owing to fears over the <a href="Shankill%20Butchers">Shankill Butchers</a> and <a href="The%20Troubles">The Troubles</a>; his brother was murdered by the <a href="Ulster%20Defence%20Association">Ulster Defence Association</a> in 1975, and a girl he met in France was killed within two weeks of arriving in Belfast. He spent four years in Wales, studying <a href="French%20language">French</a> and <a href="Celtic%20studies">Celtic studies</a>. He worked briefly as a teacher in France, at the <a href="Northern%20Ireland%20Housing%20Executive">Northern Ireland Housing Executive</a>, and at a <a href="record%20shop">record shop</a>, before opening his own <a href="restaurant">restaurant</a>, the Shay Beano, in 1982. The restaurant closed in 1991, and, having faced several <a href="%3Awikt%3Agaffe">gaffes</a>, Ó Catháin later recalled it as "one of my failings and also one of my strengths."
Ó Catháin later participated in some Irish daytime <a href="television">television</a> programmes, such as "<a href="The%20Afternoon%20Show">The Afternoon Show</a>", conducting <a href="cookery%20demonstrations">cookery demonstrations</a> on <a href="Raidi%C3%B3%20Teilif%C3%ADs%20%C3%89ireann">Raidió Teilifís Éireann</a> (RTÉ). One then-regular item, called "Meal or no Meal", was a <a href="Parody">spoof</a> on <a href="Noel%20Edmonds">Noel Edmonds</a>'s "<a href="Deal%20or%20no%20Deal">Deal or no Deal</a>". He was better-known for his programmes on <a href="TG4">TG4</a>, among them "Nua Gach Bia", "Bia's Bóthar" and "Cósta Uí Chatháin". "<a href="Bia%27s%20B%C3%B3thar">Bia's Bóthar</a>" was a <a href="Travel%20documentary">travelogue</a> initially of <a href="Ireland">Ireland</a> and then <a href="Europe">Europe</a>, presented entirely in <a href="Irish%20language">Irish</a> with <a href="English%20language">English</a> <a href="subtitles">subtitles</a> where he cooks a meal, often outdoors, from local ingredients. It ran for five series from 2001 to 2005. The final series visited many of the <a href="2004%20enlargement%20of%20the%20European%20Union">2004 accession countries</a> then joining the <a href="European%20Union">European Union</a>.
He also broadcast a radio show on <a href="world%20music">world music</a> on <a href="RT%C3%89%20Raidi%C3%B3%20na%20Gaeltachta">RTÉ Raidió na Gaeltachta</a>. It was called "Thar Tír Isteach" and went out on Friday nights, concentrating on music from <a href="Russia">Russia</a>, <a href="Poland">Poland</a>, <a href="Portugal">Portugal</a>, <a href="Africa">Africa</a>, <a href="Brazil">Brazil</a> and various other “new Irish” communities now resident in recently multicultural Ireland. Prior to that, there were long-running series on RTÉ Radio One such as "Wide World Music" as well as a classical series in Irish, "Cartlann Uí Chatháin" on <a href="RT%C3%89%20Lyric%20FM">RTÉ Lyric FM</a>.
For the most part his radio shows were themed around music, with the exception of "Love Bites" for RTÉ and "The Global Gourmet" for the BBC.
Personal life.
He speaks Irish, English and French fluently. He has authored three books, "The Irish Folk Music Guide" (1981); "Around Ireland With a Pan - Food, Tales and Recipes" (2004); and "The Hard Times Cook Book" (2009).
